Introduction
This policy has been specifically developed to manage exception reporting and work schedule reviews within Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (the Trust).

The Trust actively manages its services to provide the most effective care for patients and clients. It recognises the need to deliver safe clinical services and to ensure adherence to safe working hours protections together with access to appropriate training opportunities for all Doctors in Training (Junior Doctors).
This policy is written in accordance with the Terms and Conditions of Service for NHS Doctors and Dentists in Training (England) 2016, Version 8, December 2019 (TCS).
Scope

The purpose of exception reporting is to highlight any concerns in relation to working over and above scheduled working hours, or in examples where educational needs are not being met in line with expectations of being a doctor in training.

The principles underpinning this policy support the aim of managing safe working and training for junior doctors in a way that is both supportive to staff, and enhances the provision of the highest quality patient care

This policy will apply to all doctors in training (referred to as doctor) holding employment contracts with Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust under the Terms and Conditions of Service for NHS Doctors and Dentists in Training (England) 2016, Version 8, December 2019 (TCS) and in a General Medical Council (GMC) / General Dental Council (GDC) approved training programme.

This policy will not apply to doctors issued with an honorary contract for the purposes of attendance on the Trust's premises on behalf of another organisation except for those doctors under a host employer arrangement as part of a Health Education England lead employer contract.
This policy will also not apply for doctors where the Trust acts as the lead employer for payroll purposes for whom the host employer will be accountable.
Definitions
The definitions used in this policy are those outlined in the definitions section of the NHS doctors and Dentists in Training (England) 2016, Version 8, December 2019 (TCS).

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust (Committees)
The Trust Board has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Trust complies with the Terms and Conditions for Doctors in Training 2016, Version 8, December 2019.

The Junior Doctors Forum (JDF) represents trainees on all sites in addressing concerns pertaining to working conditions and education and training. The JDF also support and scrutinise the work of the Guardian of Safe Working (GOSW) to ensure that junior doctors' work schedules and working conditions are effectively maintained and their contractual rights upheld.
The Joint Local Negotiating Committee (JLNC) will be provided with analysis on exception reports received and the actions taken.
Roles and responsibilities within the Trust (Individuals)
The Chief Executive

The Trust's accountable officer has overall responsibility for ensuring Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal, and national requirements are met.
The Guardian of Safe Working (GOSW)
Accountable to the Trust Board and will provide assurance to the employer (and host organisation if appropriate), on compliance with safe working hours by the employer and the doctor.
Named Educational Supervisor (ES) or named Clinical Supervisor (CS) The ES / CS are responsible for providing support in developing a personalised
work schedule with the Junior Doctor in Training, assessment of any exception reports and determining the outcome of the submission.  Director of Medical Education (DME)
The DME or Associate DME will review all exception reports of an education al nature and will monitor if protected time for education is achieved, such as FY1 and FY2 teaching.
Doctor in Training

Will ensure that both their pattern of work and their total hours of work, including any and all work undertaken for any employer, whether directly or indirectly (for example through an agency or limited company), comply with the limits set out in Schedule 3 of the TCS, and that they remain safe to carry out clinical duties.
The Responsible Clinician
Is the clinician identified as responsible for the service in the circumstances where there is thought to be an immediate and substantive risk to patients and/or doctor.
Work schedules
Requirement

There is a work schedule for each training post listed in the Trust's Learning and Delivery Agreement/s with Health Education England. Work schedules will be subject to annual review at a minimum and in instances when a work schedule review is triggered by exception reports).
Generic work schedules
6.2.1  Where the post holder has been identified to the Trust, a generic work schedule will be provided to the doctor at least 8 weeks prior to commencement in the placement which will include:
Intended learning outcomes
Scheduled duties of the doctor
Number and distribution of hours for which a doctor is contracted and associated pay
Indicative time for quality improvement and patient safety activities
Opportunities for periods of formal study (other than study leave)
Personalised work schedule

6.3.1 The generic work schedule will be the basis for a personalised work schedule. The doctor should discuss with the ES / CS how they can achieve their training objectives either ahead of commencement or, as soon as possible, after the commencement of the placement.
6.3.2 Part of the personalised work schedule is the duty roster, which should be sent to the doctor at least 6 weeks prior to the commencement of the placement.
General rules for work schedules
A doctor's work schedule will normally apply for the duration of each training placement
The work schedule will be discussed as part of educational review and at a minimum an educational review should take place at the start and finish of the placement for which the work schedule applies

The doctor must disclose the nature and timing of private professional clinical work at the initial work schedule meeting with the ES/CS and inform the ES/CS in advance of any change to their disclosure. A record of the private commitments should accompany the work schedule

Full-time will be a minimum ofhours and a max ofhours per week averaged over the reference period (rota cycle or length of the placement or  weeks whichever is shorter) inclusive of annual leave calculation

Less than full time (LTFT) will be a maximum of 40 hours per week averaged over the reference period (rota cycle or length of the placement or  weeks whichever is shorter) inclusive of annual leave calculation
Exception reporting

Exception Reporting is the mechanism to facilitate prompt resolution and / or remedial action to ensure that safe working hours are maintained. An exception report may be submitted when ‘day-to-day work varies significantly and/or regularly from the agreed work schedule'. Primarily these variations will be:
Differences in the total hours of work (including opportunities for rest breaks)
Differences in the pattern of hours worked
Differences in the educational opportunities and support available to the doctor, and/or
Differences in the support available to the doctor during service commitments'

7.1.1 The variation in day-to-day work could be for reason of individual, rota management, local department or Trust issues and the variation could involve either an increase or a decrease from the usual day-to-day work. Exception reporting outcomes are anticipated to usually be one, or more, of the following:
Time off in lieu
Financial payment to the doctor
Financial penalty to the Trust
Rota review
Work schedule review
Individual or collective training
Organisational changes

7.1.2 Exception reports are assessed against the National T&Cs in place at the time of the exception occurrence. If new / amended National T&Cs are introduced for Junior Doctors in Training these will supersede the current terms and may differ from the rota rules that are currently detailed within Schedule 3 of the Junior Doctor T&Cs (Version 8, 2019).
Exception reporting eligibility
To be eligible an exception report must be:
An electronic submission to the ES or CS copied to either the DME, GOSW or both where applicable
Sent within  days of the exception or,
Sent within 7 days if it includes a claim for additional pay, or

Sent within  hours where there is an immediate safety concern. Additionally, this concern must have been raised immediately (orally) by the doctor with the clinician responsible for the service in which the risk is thought to be present (typically, this would be the head of service or the consultant on-call). In certain circumstances, the responsible clinician shall ask the doctor to raise the exception within 48 hours.
Further to efforts already undertaken locally to resolve the issue
Can be in a time period of an external major incident but the usual timeframes and remedies may not apply
Not the result of a doctor to doctor negotiated swap
Not related to locum work (locum work is excluded from all assessments and calculations as it is remunerated work that is agreed outside the main contract of
employment)
Exception reporting process

7.3.1 All exception reports must be submitted and managed through to outcome electronically via the designated software to safeguard that there is transparency and visibility of all exceptions and outcomes.
7.3.2 If there is a failure of the designated the exception report must be submitted via email to the CS / ES and copying in the GOSW added to the system by the doctor at the earliest opportunity
7.3.3 Upon receipt of the exception report the CS/ ES will make a first assessment of the exception using the following indicators:
Immediate safety concern
Rule breach incurring a financial payment
Rule breach not incurring a financial payment
Variation to work schedule hours without a rule breach (e.g. unplanned additional time worked to secure patient safety)
Variation in work schedule pattern without a rule breach
Variation to educational opportunity without a rule breach
Variation in support available to junior doctor during working hours

7.3.4 Initial discussions between the ES / CS and Doctor can take place via telephone or email if unable to meet face to face due to work / shift commitments. If the concern escalates to a level 1 work schedule review, then a face to face meeting must take place (see Appendix 2 for the exception reporting process flow chart).
Immediate safety concerns (ISC) and serious concerns
Immediate Safety Concerns usually describe factors where a doctor's fitness to work impacts on the doctor's and/or patient safety.

Where there is an immediate and substantive risk to the safety of patients or, of the doctor, the doctor will raise this immediately with the clinician responsible for the service in which the risk is thought to be present (e.g. Consultant on call) and the doctor will submit an exception report within 24 hours. The clinician responsible for the service will assess and act on the risk according to its classification as follows:
7.4.1 Serious concerns / immediate risk
Where appropriate the doctor will be granted immediate time off and/or (depending on the nature of the variation) immediate provision of support to the doctor.

This is likely to be necessary when a doctor has worked excessive hours without proper rest / breaks and their continued presence at work constitutes a real risk to the individual doctor(s) and / or patients.

The doctor should submit an exception report within 24 hours, this is copied to the Guardian and DME. Appropriate remedial action will be taken by the ES / CS and if deemed appropriate an immediate work schedule review will be undertaken
7.4.2 Serious but not immediate concerns

The doctor should submit an exception report to the ES / CS within 24 hours. A work schedule review may be required where there are frequent significant breaches of the working hours safeguards and / or a sustained inability for doctor(s) to attend training opportunities.
7.4.3 Significant but not serious concern or similar persistent or regular concerns being raised
The doctor should submit an exception report to the ES / CS within 48 hours
Financial payments
7.5.1 Exception reports that do not incur a financial penalty

Where a doctor submits an exception report for working hours in addition to their work schedule once agreed with their ES / CS this will either be given back as time off in lieu or remunerated at the doctor's contractual rate of pay (plain or premium time depending on the timing of the exception).
7.5.2 Breaches incurring a financial penalty
The breach scenarios whereby a fine can be levied on the department employing the doctor when breaches have been validated are detailed below.
The 6 breach scenarios listed below will result in a penalty rate payment to the
doctor of the additional hours and the levy of a fine on the department employing the doctor for the additional hours worked:
A breach of the 48-hour average working week (across the reference period agreed for that placement in the work schedule);or
A breach of the maximum  hour shift length; or
A breach of the maximum 72-hour limit in any consecutive 168 hour period
Where11 hours rest in a 24hr period has not been achieved (excluding non- resident on-call shifts); or
Where five hours of continuous rest between 22:00 and 07:00 during a non- resident on-call shift has not been achieved; or
Where 8 hours of total rest per  hour non-resident on-call shift has not been
achieved

7.5.3 Separate to the above, where a concern is raised that breaks have been missed on at least 25% of occasions across a four week reference period, and the concern is validated and shown to be correct, the GOSW will levy a fine at the rate of twice the relevant hourly rate for the time in which the break was not taken (see Appendix 1 for List of all Safe Working Rules).
Financial payments, penalty payments and fines
7.6.1 For transparency and audit in allocating public money the following will apply:

Exception reports which outline a breach of the work schedule with a potential financial payment will be submitted electronically within the agreed timescales with clear evidence supplied by the doctor to their ES / CS
All submissions for financial payments will be expected to be accompanied by day by day evidence from the doctor (e.g. log book, e-roster, emails) for the full period in question
Further evidence may be required from alternative sources available within the service e.g. admission data, logs of phone calls, to corroborate the evidence provided by the doctor
7.6.2 Penalty payments and fines:
The GOSW will be the authoriser of financial penalty payments

After the ES / CS has made a decision, the GOSW will review the exception report, with its identified potential financial penalty payment /fine, and either corroborate or question the decision that a financial payment is or is not required.
The department subject to the potential fine will be given 7 working days opportunity to respond to the content of the exception report.

Payments relating to a breach of the 48-hour average working week can only proceed after retrospective assessment to calculate the variance in average hours at the end of the reference period identified for that placement. The 48- hour average week reference period for any placement will be the length of the rota cycle or length of the placement whichever is the shorter.

Payments relating to a breach of the maximum 72-hour limit in any seven days will be assessed on the basis of a rolling 7 day period and the retrospective assessment to calculate the variance in hours

Payments relating to breaks missed on at least 25% of occasions will be assessed retrospectively on the basis of the submitted 4 week reference period and assessed in accordance with the classification of breaks in this policy
Breaches of the 48-hour and 72-hour limits will constitute one single penalty payment breach in their respective placement period or 7 day period
Breaches of the 48-hour limit will be calculated inclusive of annual leave allowance (summing total hours of actual work excluding leave divided over the rota cycle minus leave weeks)
Breaches of the 72-hour limit will be calculated on actual work excluding leave allowance
The circumstances of breaches incurring a financial penalty may be deemed by the GOSW to warrant the trigger of a Trust serious incident investigation
Claims that are found to be false or vexatious may result in disciplinary action
The GOSW will distribute the monies received from fines to improve training and service experience of doctors
A junior doctor forum will take part in the scrutiny of the distribution of income drawn from fines
The GOSW will report on both fines and penalty rate payments made to doctors as well as the distribution of the income from fines, to the Board no less than quarterly
The fines to the department will be invoiced by the Finance Department.
The fine payments to the doctor will be raised for payroll payment by the Medical Workforce Team on the instructions of the GOSW
Locum work is excluded from calculations for financial penalty payments
Calculation of Penalty Pay to the Doctor and Fines to the Department

7.7.1 Excluding break breach fines, payments will be made in accordance with Schedule 2, paragraph  of the T&Cs and the Pay and Conditions Circular (M&D) in force at the time the breach occurred. The calculations are that:
The department will be fined at a rate of x4 of the hourly rate (applicable contractual hourly basic or enhanced rates) for the time in question
The doctor will receive x1.5 of the applicable locum rates (basic or enhanced) for the time in question
The balance of the x4 fine will be under GOSW jurisdiction to disburse
7.7.2 Fines for missed breaks will be paid in accordance with Schedule 5, paragraph  of the TCS and the Pay and Conditions Circular (M&D) in force at the time the breach occurred.
7.7.3 Hours for payment will be rounded up to the nearest quarter hour and the calculation is that:
The department will be fined at the rate of twice the relevant hourly rate (applicable contractual hourly basic or enhanced rates) for the time in which the break was not taken
Disbursement of fines
7.8.1 An account to hold the collected fines will be set up and be under the control of the GOSW

7.8.2 Money raised through fines will be used to benefit the education, training and working environment of trainees. The GOSW is accountable to the junior doctor forum and the Board for the distribution of the income from fines.

7.8.3 Funds must not be used to supplement the facilities, study leave, IT provision and other resources that are defined by HEE as fundamental requirements for doctors in training and which should be provided by the employer/host organisation as standard
7.8.4 Fines will usually be disbursed within the departments that incurred the breaches in order to enhance the working environments within those departments
Additional time worked in unplanned exceptional circumstances to secure patient safety

7.9.1 In unplanned circumstances a doctor may consider that there is a professional duty to work beyond the hours described in the work schedule, in order to secure patient safety. In such circumstances compensation will usually be by payment, time off in lieu or a combination of these.

7.9.2 Voluntarily offering time on a goodwill unpaid basis can continue by personal choice and there may also be times when a doctor wishes to work additional hours purely for educational benefit, even if not required to do so by the department.
General rules for compensation to a doctor in exceptional circumstances

The terms of the additional time and its compensation requires authorisation by the manager (usually the on-call Consultant or Head of Service) before, during or immediately after the period of extended work
If authorisation is not obtained in accordance with the above an exception report should be submitted

Time in lieu should be the default option where the additional time worked constitutes a safe working issue. If the additional time worked causes a breach in rest requirements, then time off in lieu must be taken within 24 hours unless the doctor self declares fit for work and the manager agrees with this self- assessment in which case the time owed can be accrued to be taken at a later date. Time off in lieu arising from breaches of hours but not rest can be accrued
Accrued time off in lieu should normally be taken within three calendar months of accrual and within the same placement (where time off in lieu cannot be taken, payment will be made).
Time off in lieu should be mutually agreed with the rota co-ordinator and cannot be taken during out of hours shifts or where minimum staffing would be compromised
Where payment for additional time is while ‘acting down', payment will be made at the doctors nodal point not that of grade into which they are ‘acting down'

It is the doctors' responsibility to escalate problems as soon as they are aware of them and flag potential breaches to the supervising consultant so that where possible, steps may be taken to avoid them,
Pre-agreed additional time payments will be submitted on a timesheet by the department.
Where a manager does not authorise payment the reason for the decision will be provided to the doctor and copied to the GOSW for review
Calculation of exceptional circumstance pay and time in lieu to the doctor
7.11.1 Payments will be made in accordance with Schedule 2, paragraph 4 of the TCS and the Pay and Conditions Circular (M&D) in force at the time the hours occurred. The calculation is that:

7.11.2 The additional hours will be paid at the basic rate 1/40th of the weekly whole-time equivalent for each additional hour worked rounded up to the nearest quarter hour (applicable contractual hourly basic or enhanced rates).
7.11.3 Time in lieu will be compensated as a direct calculation of the additional hours worked.
Breaches of Safe working rules not incurring a financial penalty

table_items.text: Max 4 consecutive long shifts, at least 48 hours rest following the fourth shift
Long shift – a shift rostered to last longer than 10 hours
Max 4 consecutive long daytime/evening shifts, at least 48 hours rest following the fourth shift
Long evening shift – a long shift starting before 16:00 rostered to finish after 23:00 (a long shift starting after 16:00 will fall into the definition of a night shift)
Max 4 consecutive night shifts. At least 46 hours rest following the third or fourth such shift
Night shift – at least 3 hours of work in the period 23:00 to 06:00. Rest must be given at the conclusion of the final shift, which could be the third or fourth
Max 7 consecutive shifts (except on low intensity on-call rotas), at least 48 hours rest following the final shift

Low intensity on-call – duty on a Saturday and Sunday where 3 hours, or less, work takes place on each day, and no more than 3 episodes of work each day. Up to 12 consecutive shifts can be worked in this scenario provided that no other rule is breached
Max frequency of 1 in 3 weekends can be worked

Weekend work – any shifts/on-call duty periods where any work falls between 00.01 Saturday and 23:59 Sunday Authorisation for a rota using a pattern greater than 1 in 3 should require a clearly identified clinical reason agreed by the clinical director and seemed appropriate by the guardian of safe working
Normally at least 11 hours continuous rest between rostered shifts (separate to on-call provisions)
Breaches of rest subject to TOIL which must be given within 24hours.
No consecutive on-call periods apart from Saturday and Sunday. No more than 3 on-call periods in 7 consecutive days
A maximum of 7 consecutive on-call periods can be agreed locally where safe to do so and no other safety rules would be breached; likely to be low intensity rotas only
Day after an on-call period must not be rostered to exceed 10 hours
Where more than one on-call period is rostered consecutively (e.g. Sat/Sun), this rule applies to the day after the last on-call period
Expected rest while on-call is 8 hours per 24 hour period, of which at least 5 hours should be continuous between 22:00 and 07:00

If it is expected this will not be met, the day after must not exceed five hours. Doctor must inform employer where rest requirements not met, TOIL must be taken within 24 hours or the time will be paid
No doctor should be rostered on-call to cover the same shift as a doctor on the same rota is covering by working a shift
Unless there is a clearly defined clinical reason agreed by the clinical director and the working pattern is agreed by both the GOSW and the DME / Associate DME

data.text: (Please see Appendix 1 for list of all safe working rules)
Breaks
7.13.1 A doctor will receive at least one 30-minute paid break for a shift rostered to last more than five hours and a second 30-minute paid break for a shift rostered to last more than nine hours.

7.13.2 Breaks can be taken flexibly during the shift, and should be evenly spaced where possible. These would normally be taken separately but may if necessary be combined into one longer break. Where the breaks are combined in to one break this must be taken as near as possible to the middle of the shift.
7.13.3 No break should be taken within an hour of the shift commencing or held over to be taken at the end of the shift.
7.13.4 Breaks will not be precluded by holding a bleep, attendance at teaching or being situated in theatre areas.
7.13.5 Break Breaches on less than 25% of occasions in a 4 week period will be addressed as a variation from the work schedule rota / working pattern.
Variation from work schedule – rota / working pattern

7.14.1 Variations in day-to-day rota / working pattern that are an immediate safety concerns or breaches that incur a financial penalty, unplanned additional time to secure patient safety or breaches of the safe working rules are dealt with in Section 7 above.

7.14.2 Individual exception reports may be submitted for variations in the working pattern. Situations will be considered on a case by case basis by the ES / CS however, they will be handled in the first instance with consideration of the regularity and significance of exception reporting from the doctors within the same work area.

7.14.3 Where there is a variation from the rota / working pattern considered by the GOSW to be an unreasonable variation to the extent of occurring significantly and/or regularly, then a work schedule review may be required. Variations include both increases and decreases to the day-to-day rota / working pattern.
Variation from Work schedule – education opportunity and support

7.15.1 Individual exception reports may be submitted for variations in educational opportunities and support. Such situations will be considered on a case by case basis by the ES / CS however, they will be handled in the first instance with consideration of the regularity and significance of exception reporting from the doctors within the same work area.

7.15.2 Where there are variations to the education and support in the work schedule, which are considered by the DME to be an unreasonable variation to the extent of occurring significantly and/or regularly, then a work schedule review may be required.
Major Incident

7.16.1 In the event of the Trust declaring an external major incident, financial payments under this policy are suspended for the duration of the incident. Exception reports may still be submitted where there is opportunity to do so.
Honorary contract holders – doctors in training

7.17.1 Doctors holding honorary contracts with the Trust will follow this policy where the duties are carried out for this Trust. The GOSW, as the host GOSW, will ensure that information is available to the GOSW at the lead employer as well as to the host board.
Work schedule reviews
Circumstances of a work schedule review
8.1.1 A work schedule review can be triggered by one or more exception reports, or by a request from a doctor, an ES / CS, a Manager or the GOSW.
8.1.2 A work schedule review should consider safe working, working hours, educational concerns and/or issues relating to service delivery.

8.1.3 Where the exception report is submitted for reason of an immediate safety concern (immediate and substantive risk to the safety of patients or of the doctor making the report) then an Initial Review should occur at the earliest reasonable opportunity and within 7 working days. Such an exception report will be further to the doctor's immediate verbal conversation with the responsible clinician to agree the most appropriate real-time solution.
Review stages
8.2.1 The work schedule review structure comprises Initial Review (part of any exception report response, Level 1, Level 2 and Final Stage process.

8.2.2 An Initial Review takes place with the doctor and the ES/ CS ideally no later than 7 working days after receipt of an exception report. It is anticipated that in the first instance, that concerns raised in exception reports, will be addressed by the local clinical team, whether this is by the ES/CS when in the same service or, supported by other member/s of the local clinical team such as Clinical Supervisor or on-call Consultant.

8.2.3 The details of the exception report will have automatically been shared electronically with the ES/CS, GOSW or DME and GOSW Administrator upon submission of the report, so that an appropriate oversight can be maintained of patterns emerging which merit further exploration.
8.2.4 The role of the GOSW Administrator will be to monitor all submitted exception reports and escalate concerns as appropriate. If a doctor disagrees with the
outcome of the Initial Review then a Level 1 review may be requested within 7 working days of the notification of the decision.

8.2.5 A Level 1 review takes place with the doctor and the ES ideally no later than 7 working days after the outcome of the Initial Review. This may also be triggered for instance by a pattern of concerns as identified by the GOSW / Medical Workforce or DME as well as at the specific request of an individual doctor(s) and should similarly occur within 7 days. Depending on the nature of the concern(s), the ES is likely to require support and guidance from the operational clinical teams, Medical Workforce, the GOSW and / or the DME. If a doctor(s) is dissatisfied with the outcome of the Level 1 review then a request for a Level 2 review may be made within 14 working days of notification of the Level 1 decision.

8.2.4 A Level 2 review takes place with the ES/CS, the doctor, a service representative and a nominee either of the DME (where the request pertains to training concerns) or GOSW (where the request pertains to safe working concerns) ideally no more than  working days after receipt of the Level 2 request.

8.2.5 If dissatisfied with the outcome of the Level 2 review, the doctor may request a Final Stage work review within  working days of notification of the decision. The Final Stage process is a formal meeting under the final stage of the Trust's Grievance Policy and Procedure with the addition of the DME or nominated deputy in attendance. In the circumstances of an appeal of a decision by the GOSW, the Meeting will include a representative from the BMA nominated from outside of the employer/host organisation. The latter will be provided by the union within one calendar month. The timescale of the Meeting will be in accordance with the Trust's Grievance Policy and Procedure. The Meeting outcome will be final and will be communicated in writing and copied to the GOSW.

8.2.6 If, at any stage in the work schedule review process, changes to individual or collective rotas / working patterns are identified as the appropriate solution to the concerns this will be undertaken in accordance with Section 9 below; including discussion and agreement with doctors working on the rota in question, service representatives, educational representatives and Medical Workforce (see Appendix 2 for the process for a work schedule review).
Changes to work schedules
Types of change

9.1.1 Work schedule changes agreed between the doctor and the ES/CS are able to be made prospectively at any time during the doctor's placement where they do not impact upon pay or, the contracted work pattern or, have a wider impact within the service/ Trust which require other parties to be involved. A written record of the change should be made and the revised work schedule returned to the rota co- ordinator, Clinical Tutor DME, ES/CS, and Medical Workforce
9.1.2 Changes which impact upon pay or, the contracted work pattern or, have a wider impact within the service / Trust should only be made as a result of a completed work schedule review.

9.1.3 Major organisational changes, such as service reconfiguration, will continue to be managed via the Trust's Organisational Change Policy. This will include any changes which may lead to redundancy and / or redeployment.

9.1.4 Wherever possible local departmental changes will be agreed through discussions and collaborative team working, the need for which may be triggered by Exception Reporting and Work Schedule Reviews.
Rota pattern review
9.2.1  Rotas will be reviewed as follows:
Request raised e.g. by Doctor/s, Supervisor/ES, Department, Medical HR Manager, GOSW, DME (the origin of the request to be noted for determination of pay protection)

Medical Workforce Adviser, Department representative/s and doctor(s) working on the rota in question review the current rota/working pattern, model alternative options, agree preferred template and proposed implementation date
Once template approved implementation proceeds in accordance with proposed timeline and the terms of amendments to pay from work schedule changes
This process will constitute a joint work schedule review but not preclude access to the individual work schedule review process.
Changes to the work schedule affecting pay
9.3.1 When work schedule changes have been finalised under the Trust's work pattern review process the following will apply for pay:

9.3.2 Where pay of individual doctor(s) is increased by a change to the work schedule, pay will be altered prospectively from the date that the change is implemented except in exceptional circumstances

9.3.3 Where total pay of individual doctor(s) is decreased as a result of a change to the work schedule required by the Trust, then pay will be protected until the end of the particular placement covered by that work schedule. Protection will not extend to any subsequent placement, including a placement where the doctor returns at a later date to the same post

9.3.4 Where total pay of individual doctor(s) is decreased as a result of a change requested by the doctor, the doctors total pay will be reduced in line with the change in the work schedule, from the date that the change is implemented

9.3.5 This will apply to all involved parties whether it is a standalone rota / work pattern or a shared rota / work pattern. The origin of the request to change the rota / work pattern will be determined and clearly documented at the outset.
Assurance
The GOSW
10.1.1 The GOSW is responsible for providing assurance of the compliance to safe working hours by the employer and the doctor.
10.1.2 The GOSW will:
Be a senior appointment not holding any other role within the management structure
Receive copies of all exception reports in respect of safe working hours

Escalate issues relating to working hours, raised in exception reports, to the relevant executive director, or equivalent, for decision and action, where these have not been addressed at departmental level and if it remains unresolved, submit an exceptional report to the next meeting of the Board
Require intervention to mitigate any identified risk to doctor or patient safety in a timescale commensurate with the severity of the risk
Require a work schedule review to be undertaken, where there are regular or persistent breaches in safe working hours, which have not been addressed
Have the authority to intervene in any instance where the GSWH considers the safety of patients and/or doctors is compromised, or that issues are not being resolved satisfactorily
Report to the Board no less than quarterly inclusive of data on rota gaps and provide the report to the Local Negotiating Committee (LNC)
Inform the Board of post / placement issues that cannot be remedied locally for the Board to raise with partner organisations
With the DME, establish a Junior Doctors Forum
Concerns regarding the GOSW

10.2.1 The BMA, other recognised trade union, or the Junior Doctors Forum will raise and concerns regarding the GOSW with the Chief Medical Officer. If not properly addressed or resolved, concerns can be escalated to the senior independent director on the Board of Directors.
Training requirements

Junior Doctors in Training are provided with training from the GOSW as part of their trust induction on how to submit an exception report via the trust electronic systems and the circumstances in which they should be submitted

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Joint Local Negotiating Committee (JLNC), which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies for Medical and Dental staff. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

the needs of all individuals (refer to appendix 3).

Appendix 1: Safe working rules

table_items.text: A GOSW fine will apply if this rule is breached
Max 72 hours work in any consecutive period of 168 hours
A GOSW fine will apply if this rule is breached
On-call periods can be up to 24 hours
46-hours of rest required after a number of rostered night shifts
Max 4 consecutive long shifts, at least 48 hours rest following the fourth shift
Long shift – a shift rostered to last longer than 10 hours
Max 4 consecutive long daytime/evening shifts, at least 48 hours rest following the fourth shift
Long evening shift – a long shift starting before 16:00 rostered to finish after 23:00 (a long shift starting after 16:00 will fall into the definition of a night shift)
Max 4 consecutive night shifts. At least 46 hours rest following the third or fourth such shift
Night shift – at least 3 hours of work in the period 23:00 to 06:00. Rest must be given at the conclusion of the final shift, which could be the third or fourth
Max 7 consecutive shifts (except on low intensity on-call rotas), at least 48 hours rest following the final shift

Low intensity on-call – duty on a Saturday and Sunday where 3 hours, or less, work takes place on each day, and no more than 3 episodes of work each day. Up to 12 consecutive shifts can be worked in this scenario provided that no other rule is breached
Max frequency of 1 in 3 weekends can be worked

Weekend work – any shifts/on-call duty periods where any work falls between 00.01 Saturday and 23:59 Sunday Authorisation for a rota using a pattern greater than 1 in 3 should require a clearly identified clinical reason agreed by the Clinical Director and be deemed appropriate by the GOSW
Normally at least 11 hours continuous rest between rostered shifts (separate on-call provisions below)

Breaches of rest subject to time off in lieu (TOIL) which must be given within 24 hours. In exceptional circumstances where rest reduced to fewer than 8 hours, time will be paid at a penalty rate & doctor not expected to work more than five hours the following day. A GOSW fine will apply in this circumstance.
30 minute break for 5 hours work, a second 30 minute break for more than 9 hours A third 30 minute break for a night shift rostered to last 12 hours or

A GOSW fine will apply if breaks are missed on at least 25 per cent of occasions across a 4 week reference period. Breaks should be taken separately but if combined must be taken as near as possible to the middle of the shift.
No consecutive on-call periods apart from Saturday and Sunday. No more than 3 on-call periods in 7 consecutive days
A maximum of 7 consecutive on-call periods can be agreed locally where safe to do so and no other safety rules would be breached; likely to be low intensity rotas only
Day after an on-call period must not be rostered to exceed 10 hours
Where more than one on-call period is rostered consecutively (e.g. Sat/Sun), this rule applies to the day after the last on-call period
Expected rest while on-call is 8 hours per 24 hour period, of which at least 5 hours should be continuous between 22:00 and 07:00

If it is expected this will not be met, the day after must not exceed five hours. Doctor must inform employer where rest requirements not met, TOIL must be taken within 24 hours or the time will be paid A GOSW fine will apply in this circumstance
No doctor should be rostered on- call to cover the same shift as a doctor on the same rota is covering by working a shift
Unless there is a clearly defined clinical reason agreed by the clinical director and the working pattern is agreed by both the GOSW and the DME.
